claim: In New York, Christianity is the most common religion, followed by 60% of the population.

supporting.text: According to the Pew Research Center's 2014 Religious Landscape Study, Christianity was the most common religion in New York, with approximately 60% of the population identifying as Christian.

attacks.text: According to the Pew Research Center's 2014 Religious Landscape Study, Christianity was the most common religion in New York, with approximately 60% of the population identifying as Christian.
The Pew Research Center's 2014 data is outdated and may not reflect current religious demographics in New York.

More recent surveys, such as the Public Religion Research Institute's 2020 study, confirm that Christianity remains the dominant religion in New York, though the percentage may have slightly decreased.
The 60% figure includes all Christian denominations, but no single denomination holds a majority, making it misleading to generalize Christianity as a monolithic group.
Even if no single denomination holds a majority, the collective influence and cultural dominance of Christianity in New York remain significant.
The study's methodology may undercount non-Christian religious groups, particularly immigrant communities with diverse faiths.
Pew Research Center is a reputable source with rigorous methodology, making significant undercounting unlikely.
